I've played the game almost entirely on mobile, and I've read some of the negative reviews here, and think some of them are being a bit unfair/unrealistic. So here's the top six reasons why people gave this a negative review:

---The game is made by Akatsuki, and they haven't been made the best choices for the players

That's true--there's a lot of people that have been burned by them, so if you dislike them, I wouldn't bother playing the game. I think this game is good, but I can see why someone would have an issue with the company and not even give the game the time of day.

---The banners don't separate weapons and characters

That's also true--one of the few issues I really have with the game. So if you pull a banner, and the animation makes it look like you're going to get something good, and then you pull a weapon instead of the character? That hope they give you just hurts a bit more. I don't know why they chose to do banners like this, but it's extremely frustrating.

---The game has an auto battling button, and you can just click it and make everything boring

This one is interesting because A.) the game isn't making you auto battle, and B.) sometimes you actually need to battle because the AI can be stupid. I enjoy the auto battle button sometimes when I just want to do the battle without much input, and I'm not sure why that's a negative--that's more of a QoL function than anything.

---The game doesn't have a lot of end game content

That's true, but the game is fairly new and it is adding content every several weeks. So you could make the case for that being a reason why you don't play, or you could just...wait until there's more content to play.

---People only focus on playing with the best characters, and many others get left behind

This comment I saw a few times, I thought it was weird--people were complaining that there is a meta and that some characters aren't even effective or useful. And while that is true, you'd be surprised at how many lower characters are extremely useful in higher/end game content--there are at least four to five 4 star characters that are amazing support for a team and allow your star characters to do tons of damage.

---The gacha and rates are somehow more terrible in this game than other gatcha games

For me personally, I've been lucky to get almost every character and their weapons from the banners. I've had some bad luck, but the game gives you plenty of opportunities to get characters and their weapons. But that is for me personally. What I will say is I've played other gatcha games, and this game doesn't seem as terrible--in fact, a lot of the comments on reddit say that this game is fairly mild when it comes to gatcha tactics. But you may find that it's terrible just based on bad luck.

Honestly, I really enjoy this game--it's not something you need to grind at, but you check in every few times a day to burn through your energy, do a few battles, and then go do something else. I hate gatcha games that make you feel like you have to check them every 10-20 mins and they're so busy that it just becomes a job to play them. I think some of the negative comments are warranted, but some of them aren't, and for me personally? I believe this game gets a positive review.

I should start by saying that the higher up executives of the company Akatsuki Games should not be trusted, they again and again disappoint their fans by giving up on their projects, most recently they developed the amazing game Tribe Nine which was the best Gacha game I have ever played in 10 years playing Gacha games, only to suddenly end support, fire the developers and abandon their fans in 3 months, this company has proven that it does not deserve your money.

With that out of the way, I did still want to give this game a fair shot as I did not want to simply review bomb this and go on with my life, for as much as I hate the higher ups, the developers, artists and writters working on this game deserve a chance. As of right now I've played the game on mobile for about 3 weeks and have completed quite literally every piece of content currently available.

This game is a very standard turn based rpg team building gacha game, with most of it's systems being very clearly taken from one of the most popular gacha games of the current day, Honkai Star Rail. The break bar system, the two attacks and an ultimate per character, the character order list, it's all an obvious copy of HSR (that game already being a copy of the Trails series and FFX). In a way that's good, if it ain't broke don't fix it and all that, but Kaiju No8 doesn't do anything particularly special to make me reccomend it over just playing Honkai Star Rail, which has in my opinion a very good story. Just to be done with comparisons, the one thing I do quite like that Kaiju No8 does is their version of the break bar system, instead of it being a bar that is depleted slowly like in HSR, it is instead based on number of attacks that correspond to a certain group of elements and weaknesses, that I think makes it much more strategic to think about your attacks, at certain points you'll find yourself thinking "should I use this buff skill now or do a regular attack to get closer to breaking the bar" or "should I use the ultimate to help break the bar or to do more damage after it's broker", and that can be quite fun. 

Next I should mention the story, if you're a fan of the series already you will probably have a fine time with the new content that is exclusive to this game, the new characters are interesting enough even if they have very little screen time, and the character exclusive little chapters are charming, but I couldn't reccomend this game to anyone who is not already a fan of the series, half of the story content is just a worse retelling of the first season of the anime that uses the in game models to tell the story, and while you can tell good stories with little animation, in this case it just ends up looking weird and cheap.

The most positive point in my opinion is the graphics and visuals in combat, the fidelity with the style of the original work is impressive and the models and animations are on point there, on that regard I have zero complaints.

Now for the biggest complaint of this game is just how barren it is, overrall for content you have the Story Mode, farming for leveling and other powerups, and the endgame mode which are just high level battles with turn limit based rewards, and that's quite honestly about it, there have been a few events like the kaiju raid, but those just end up becoming an extra daily to skip after the first time you do it. There's also the expedition mode which is this weird roguelike autobattle thing, it's honestly fun but it's a completely separate game and aside from weekly rewards theres not much reason to do it. 
Yeah there's no exploration, no unique gamemode that can go infinitely, or even a changing endgame mode, once you're done you're done and you'll be left waiting, which is a very bad look for this game overrall.

In conclusion, Kaiju No. 8 is an okay game that takes a lot from other sources and does an okay work with it, but the lack of content or anything really special makes it a hard sell for anyone that's not already a fan of the original series.
Considering the terrible past of Akatsuki Games, I would only reccomend this game if it blew me away the same way Tribe Nine did, it's okay overrall but it didn't even come close to it, and as such, unless you are a big fan of Kaiju No8, I don't reccomend this game to you.

[h3]Don't give Akatsuki your money. Seriously.[/h3]

First of all - the delay for the Steam release already makes the situation bad. We didn't have any news about it until almost two weeks have passed, and the statement was literally "we didn't finish making the port". (the Steam page of Kaiju8 game and their official socials still have "coming soon" in descriptions, they didn't even bother). Their communication department is awful, and have been like this for a while with the previous games too. Late underwhelming character teasers, no proper marketing, no proper patch notes, lack of interactions with the community, nearly no support feedback.
The port itself isn't that good either, if you are interested. No advanced graphics options, no higher resolution for the cutscenes or sprites, controls are the same as in any of your average mobile ports: you can "tap", and... Yeah, that's kinda it. No keyboard shortcuts. Plus there are some annoying things such as jitter effect on the models and forced lack of smoothing even on "max quality" setting. You can't disable the effects or make the quality better, just as mentioned above. Not to mention the PC only players are missing out on an entire month of resources, and will NOT receive any compensation ever, nor did we get any sort of celebration for the PC release. PC only players, who were excited for the release in August, are now in an active disadvantage in terms of progression and rewards. If you wanted to get a unit that was released for mobile only just a few weeks ago - too bad. Their banner is gone, wait for a rerun.

[u]Now to the actual game.[/u]

[b]Story[/b] - since I haven't interacted with the ip before, I can't judge how faithful it is. My apologies, will have to skip this part.

[b]Gameplay[/b] - it's hsr, plain and simple. Not like it's bad, you can have some fun with it. But the UI is quite confusing, skill buttons lack information (you'll have to hold character icons to see the detailed skill info), no turn indicator (it only shows in fierce battle) which makes it hard to manage the buffs, AI for the auto is kind of dumb, spamming the skill even if it's not needed, and the animations are too damn long (and lack impact sometimes). X2 speed doesn't help much.

[b]Graphics[/b] - just as told in the Steam release rent, it's not good for a PC port. Character models are decently done (but lack emotions and have awful lipsync), their animations are smooth (for the most part, story cutscenes are kind of awkward), and the animations do get frequently re-used (attack and follow-up animations are the same, ult animations get re-used in the story, gacha animation literally being the same as protag's ult but slightly shinier). I still respect those responsible for the actual art part, both 2D and 3D. They did their best, just probably weren't given enough time.

[b]Progression[/b] - one of the most scammy parts. If you log in once a day - you are missing out on at least half of the resources you could get. But to be fair, if you are a patient casual player that is not bothered by fomo - it probably won't stress you too much and you can ignore this paragraph. If you are not - prepare to log in twice a day and plan your routine, or the progress will suffer.
The worst part though is the gear system. You have to literally gamble both for the rarity and the main stat. Doesn't sound too bad as there are no level ups like in hoyo games, but there is no way to guarantee yourself a gold rarity set piece (5 star), and the highest rarity material you can get to make a set piece is purple rarity (4 star). Meaning it only has a CHANCE to get you a gold. Plus the stat reroll is expensive. And did I mention the set bonus actually scales off the set rarity? Not all pieces are gold? You miss out on quite a few percents. 
Each replaced piece gives you "recycling" mat, and you can buy more materials for making the equipment, but the whole process is insanely miserable if you even slightly care for the stats and set bonuses.

[b]Music and voices[/b] - it's alright, I guess. Voice acting is actually very good, and I didn't expect less from the professional cast. The soundtrack is a bit generic, but maybe someone could enjoy it. The variety in tracks is not much, so they do get boring after a while...

[b]Content and gacha[/b] - there is no content. You finish the story, you finish fierce battle (aka mirror from hsr), and you have nothing to do aside from maxing all your teams. Gacha income? There is none. The game tricks you into thinking it's generous by giving away characters, dupes, tickets and currency. But once you clear everything mentioned before - you get 1/3 of a pull daily, and nothing more. The "fierce battle" updates once a month, but it gives you less than a ten pull, so don't expect miracles. What about the events tho? There are none. Two log-in campaigns that last a week, one "event" that doesn't give pull currency. That's all I was met with on PC release. I don't expect improvements from Akatsuki in this department, especially not hoyo levels of creativity or Nikke levels of generousity.
 Speaking of pulls, what about the banners? There is no weapon banner, BUT just because weapon and character are in the same one. 3% for a featured unit, 5% for their featured weapon. No soft pity, no hard pity. BUT the tokens you get for pulling don't expire, similarly to Nikke. You can buy a unit or their signature weapon if you want, but it will take A LOT of pulls (250 for a unit, 150 for a weapon), and you will never have enough of those with an income like that. Game can shower you with random 5 stars on every ten, or it can leave you with nothing after 200. You will never know until you get into this situation. Imagine getting two copies of a weapon in 150 pulls, yet not a single copy of the character it was made for. Couldn't be me of course...

[i]The game overall clearly expects you to spend in order to make any sort of progress. Limited energy with no overflow yet at least two paid stamina packs, battle pass with limited weapons (but not too much value imo) just like in your favourite hoyo games, huge amounts of pulls required to get the character. God forbid if you want to get them to max dupes (that being 6) OR their weapon (4 dupes). It's your average anime IP cashgrab. Looks good on the surface, can be enjoyed, but will occasionally remind you what it is. All gacha games are predatory, but some just hide it better than the others. This one kind of fails at that. Even if you are a fan of Kaiju no.8 - I'd avoid getting into it. Maybe complete the story if you are interested in the new original characters or casual conversations between the cast members in chats, but that's all I can say.[/i]

I should start by saying that the higher up executives of the company Akatsuki Games should not be trusted, they again and again disappoint their fans by giving up on their projects, most recently they developed the amazing game Tribe Nine which was the best Gacha game I have ever played in 10 years playing Gacha games, only to suddenly end support, fire the developers and abandon their fans in 3 months, this company has proven that it does not deserve your money.

With that out of the way, I did still want to give this game a fair shot as I did not want to simply review bomb this and go on with my life, for as much as I hate the higher ups, the developers, artists and writters working on this game deserve a chance. As of right now I've played the game on mobile for about 3 weeks and have completed quite literally every piece of content currently available.

This game is a very standard turn based rpg team building gacha game, with most of it's systems being very clearly taken from one of the most popular gacha games of the current day, Honkai Star Rail. The break bar system, the two attacks and an ultimate per character, the character order list, it's all an obvious copy of HSR (that game already being a copy of the Trails series and FFX). In a way that's good, if it ain't broke don't fix it and all that, but Kaiju No8 doesn't do anything particularly special to make me reccomend it over just playing Honkai Star Rail, which has in my opinion a very good story. Just to be done with comparisons, the one thing I do quite like that Kaiju No8 does is their version of the break bar system, instead of it being a bar that is depleted slowly like in HSR, it is instead based on number of attacks that correspond to a certain group of elements and weaknesses, that I think makes it much more strategic to think about your attacks, at certain points you'll find yourself thinking "should I use this buff skill now or do a regular attack to get closer to breaking the bar" or "should I use the ultimate to help break the bar or to do more damage after it's broker", and that can be quite fun. 

Next I should mention the story, if you're a fan of the series already you will probably have a fine time with the new content that is exclusive to this game, the new characters are interesting enough even if they have very little screen time, and the character exclusive little chapters are charming, but I couldn't reccomend this game to anyone who is not already a fan of the series, half of the story content is just a worse retelling of the first season of the anime that uses the in game models to tell the story, and while you can tell good stories with little animation, in this case it just ends up looking weird and cheap.

The most positive point in my opinion is the graphics and visuals in combat, the fidelity with the style of the original work is impressive and the models and animations are on point there, on that regard I have zero complaints.

Now for the biggest complaint of this game is just how barren it is, overrall for content you have the Story Mode, farming for leveling and other powerups, and the endgame mode which are just high level battles with turn limit based rewards, and that's quite honestly about it, there have been a few events like the kaiju raid, but those just end up becoming an extra daily to skip after the first time you do it. There's also the expedition mode which is this weird roguelike autobattle thing, it's honestly fun but it's a completely separate game and aside from weekly rewards theres not much reason to do it. 
Yeah there's no exploration, no unique gamemode that can go infinitely, or even a changing endgame mode, once you're done you're done and you'll be left waiting, which is a very bad look for this game overrall.

In conclusion, Kaiju No. 8 is an okay game that takes a lot from other sources and does an okay work with it, but the lack of content or anything really special makes it a hard sell for anyone that's not already a fan of the original series.
Considering the terrible past of Akatsuki Games, I would only reccomend this game if it blew me away the same way Tribe Nine did, it's okay overrall but it didn't even come close to it, and as such, unless you are a big fan of Kaiju No8, I don't reccomend this game to you.

[h3]Don't give Akatsuki your money. Seriously.[/h3]

First of all - the delay for the Steam release already makes the situation bad. We didn't have any news about it until almost two weeks have passed, and the statement was literally "we didn't finish making the port". (the Steam page of Kaiju8 game and their official socials still have "coming soon" in descriptions, they didn't even bother). Their communication department is awful, and have been like this for a while with the previous games too. Late underwhelming character teasers, no proper marketing, no proper patch notes, lack of interactions with the community, nearly no support feedback.
The port itself isn't that good either, if you are interested. No advanced graphics options, no higher resolution for the cutscenes or sprites, controls are the same as in any of your average mobile ports: you can "tap", and... Yeah, that's kinda it. No keyboard shortcuts. Plus there are some annoying things such as jitter effect on the models and forced lack of smoothing even on "max quality" setting. You can't disable the effects or make the quality better, just as mentioned above. Not to mention the PC only players are missing out on an entire month of resources, and will NOT receive any compensation ever, nor did we get any sort of celebration for the PC release. PC only players, who were excited for the release in August, are now in an active disadvantage in terms of progression and rewards. If you wanted to get a unit that was released for mobile only just a few weeks ago - too bad. Their banner is gone, wait for a rerun.

[u]Now to the actual game.[/u]

[b]Story[/b] - since I haven't interacted with the ip before, I can't judge how faithful it is. My apologies, will have to skip this part.

[b]Gameplay[/b] - it's hsr, plain and simple. Not like it's bad, you can have some fun with it. But the UI is quite confusing, skill buttons lack information (you'll have to hold character icons to see the detailed skill info), no turn indicator (it only shows in fierce battle) which makes it hard to manage the buffs, AI for the auto is kind of dumb, spamming the skill even if it's not needed, and the animations are too damn long (and lack impact sometimes). X2 speed doesn't help much.

[b]Graphics[/b] - just as told in the Steam release rent, it's not good for a PC port. Character models are decently done (but lack emotions and have awful lipsync), their animations are smooth (for the most part, story cutscenes are kind of awkward), and the animations do get frequently re-used (attack and follow-up animations are the same, ult animations get re-used in the story, gacha animation literally being the same as protag's ult but slightly shinier). I still respect those responsible for the actual art part, both 2D and 3D. They did their best, just probably weren't given enough time.

[b]Progression[/b] - one of the most scammy parts. If you log in once a day - you are missing out on at least half of the resources you could get. But to be fair, if you are a patient casual player that is not bothered by fomo - it probably won't stress you too much and you can ignore this paragraph. If you are not - prepare to log in twice a day and plan your routine, or the progress will suffer.
The worst part though is the gear system. You have to literally gamble both for the rarity and the main stat. Doesn't sound too bad as there are no level ups like in hoyo games, but there is no way to guarantee yourself a gold rarity set piece (5 star), and the highest rarity material you can get to make a set piece is purple rarity (4 star). Meaning it only has a CHANCE to get you a gold. Plus the stat reroll is expensive. And did I mention the set bonus actually scales off the set rarity? Not all pieces are gold? You miss out on quite a few percents. 
Each replaced piece gives you "recycling" mat, and you can buy more materials for making the equipment, but the whole process is insanely miserable if you even slightly care for the stats and set bonuses.

[b]Music and voices[/b] - it's alright, I guess. Voice acting is actually very good, and I didn't expect less from the professional cast. The soundtrack is a bit generic, but maybe someone could enjoy it. The variety in tracks is not much, so they do get boring after a while...

[b]Content and gacha[/b] - there is no content. You finish the story, you finish fierce battle (aka mirror from hsr), and you have nothing to do aside from maxing all your teams. Gacha income? There is none. The game tricks you into thinking it's generous by giving away characters, dupes, tickets and currency. But once you clear everything mentioned before - you get 1/3 of a pull daily, and nothing more. The "fierce battle" updates once a month, but it gives you less than a ten pull, so don't expect miracles. What about the events tho? There are none. Two log-in campaigns that last a week, one "event" that doesn't give pull currency. That's all I was met with on PC release. I don't expect improvements from Akatsuki in this department, especially not hoyo levels of creativity or Nikke levels of generousity.
 Speaking of pulls, what about the banners? There is no weapon banner, BUT just because weapon and character are in the same one. 3% for a featured unit, 5% for their featured weapon. No soft pity, no hard pity. BUT the tokens you get for pulling don't expire, similarly to Nikke. You can buy a unit or their signature weapon if you want, but it will take A LOT of pulls (250 for a unit, 150 for a weapon), and you will never have enough of those with an income like that. Game can shower you with random 5 stars on every ten, or it can leave you with nothing after 200. You will never know until you get into this situation. Imagine getting two copies of a weapon in 150 pulls, yet not a single copy of the character it was made for. Couldn't be me of course...

[i]The game overall clearly expects you to spend in order to make any sort of progress. Limited energy with no overflow yet at least two paid stamina packs, battle pass with limited weapons (but not too much value imo) just like in your favourite hoyo games, huge amounts of pulls required to get the character. God forbid if you want to get them to max dupes (that being 6) OR their weapon (4 dupes). It's your average anime IP cashgrab. Looks good on the surface, can be enjoyed, but will occasionally remind you what it is. All gacha games are predatory, but some just hide it better than the others. This one kind of fails at that. Even if you are a fan of Kaiju no.8 - I'd avoid getting into it. Maybe complete the story if you are interested in the new original characters or casual conversations between the cast members in chats, but that's all I can say.[/i]

First of all, I am a very big fan of this franchise and have played many gacha games. That's why it makes me all the more sad that this game is the way it is.
(Though it is playable on Steam Deck and Linux, this is a big W for an gacha game!)

Like I said, it's a gacha game, so you need to play it every day or pull your credit card to get enough rewards to pull all the possible characters. Right now you get enough rewards to unlock every character with his weapon, though the catch is there will come a time where you won't be able to get this many rewards anymore. All the while you may also be out of luck and don't unlock your character at all, as there doesn't seem to be any pity mechanic in this game like ZZZ or Genshin have. So while good enough right now, the gacha system could be improved in my eyes to feel more consistent and less punishing.

You acquire "tickets" for pulls, with one ticket meaning one pull. The other way is using the game's own currency which is similar to ZZZ polychrom. The problem is that tickets and said currency can't be mixed which extends grinding if you want to do ten pulls at once. Grinding energy can add to the padding of the game but there is one mechanic i personally like in which you can skip the combat to get your rewards early. This avoids redundant combat missions, but in case you really like the turned based combat system you can still do it the manual way.
The main gripe comes with that you'll need resources to level up your characters, which may result in you just waiting another day to be able to continue the story, which drags it on even more.

As you can see, the game does have its gripes but if you can overlook the padding mechanics and the waiting periods, there is much fun to be had.
